title: Synthetic Recap
body:
PHILADELPHIA (AP) — The record books will show it was a 13-point victory for the Atlanta Hawks, but the history made Thursday night belonged to one man and one man alone. In a stunning, singular display of offensive firepower, Steve Smith authored a performance for the ages, pouring in a career-high 47 points to eviscerate the Philadelphia 76ers, 117-104.

From the opening tip, Smith was simply unstoppable. He attacked the rim with ferocity and scored from the perimeter with a shooter’s grace, leaving a trail of frustrated defenders in his wake. The Sixers had no answer. Every contested shot seemed to find the bottom of the net; every drive was a masterclass in body control and finishing. Smith wasn't just scoring; he was putting on a clinic, a one-man offensive system that Philadelphia’s defense was powerless to decode.

While Smith’s majestic performance rightfully commands the spotlight, he was not without support. Dikembe Mutombo anchored the paint with 14 points and a game-high 17 rebounds, his intimidating presence allowing Smith to operate freely on the perimeter. Mookie Blaylock orchestrated the offense with precision, dishing out 11 assists to keep the Hawks’ engine humming.

The Sixers, led by a valiant 23 points from Jerry Stackhouse and 20 from Derrick Coleman, fought to stay within striking distance, but Smith’s relentless assault was a tide they could not hold back. Each time Philadelphia threatened a run, Smith answered with a cold-blooded jumper or a determined drive, snuffing out their hope and sucking the life from the arena.

When the final buzzer sounded, the score was almost a footnote. The real story was the breathtaking, career-defining night from Steve Smith—a 47-point explosion that will be remembered not just as a win, but as a legendary performance etched into the annals of the game.
